data.title: Add editorCursor.background
data.body:
We are adding foreground and background settings for the terminal cursor -
 https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/30294

Currently when using a block cursor, the editor sets the color of the overlapped character to the opposite of the cursor foreground color. But you can end up with strange color combinations, and it's not necessarily high contrast. For example with `"editorCursor.foreground": "#808080"`, the character color is also #808080.

data.title: Word wrap settings are forgotten when switching tabs
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:13:05.928Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0
- Extensions: none
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Add text long enough to go off the right side of your screen.
2. Open a file and turn on `View: Toggle Word Wrap`.
3. See that the line has wrapped.
4. Switch tabs to another file.
5. Switch back
6. See that the word wrap setting has been forgotten and the text is extending past your screen again

data.title: Smoke Test not switched to Tasks 2.0: "is able to select 'Git' output" fails
data.body: It seems like this test expects the Output panel to be visible, but the tasks now run in the terminal.

data.title: Block comment fails with multiple inline blocks
data.body:
Given the following line of code:

`
if( editor.document.isDirty === false )
`

selecting "editor" and doing a block comment (correctly) results in

`
if( /*editor*/.document.isDirty === false )
`

then selecting "false" and doing a block comment (correctly) results in 

`
if( /*editor*/.document.isDirty === /*false*/ )
`

then selecting "isDirty" and doing a block comment (incorrectly) results in 

`
if( editor*/.document.isDirty === /*false )
`

data.title: Smoke test not switched to Tasks 2.0: smoke test fails
data.body:
The smoketest build task produces the expected error, but the test is not able to find it. Maybe due to color or the `x` on the line in front of it.

```
  4) Smoke Test Suite Tasks ensures that build task produces error in index.js:

      AssertionError: Output does not contain error in index.js
      + expected - actual

      -false
      +true

      at Context.<anonymous> (out/tests/tasks.js:54:24)
      at Generator.next (<anonymous>)
      at fulfilled (out/tests/tasks.js:8:58)
```

And this one for probably the same reason:

```
  5) Smoke Test Suite Tasks verifies build error is reflected in 'Problems View':
     Error: the string "Could not retrieve the element in 45 seconds." was thrown, throw an Error :)
```

data.title: Smoke test autoupdates on MacOS
data.body:
- Run smoke test on 1.14
- If a test takes long enough, it will "update" and regress to the released stable version

It should set the update channel to "none" before running tests.

data.title: Command+Click on line in OUTPUT console should go to line in already open file
data.body:
_From @tylerb on July 10, 2017 18:34_

Repro:

1. Use two code views
2. Left view open an unrelated file
3. Right view open a test file with a failing test
4. Run test to generate output in the OUTPUT pane
5. Click on the left view to select it
6. command+click the failing line in OUTPUT

Expected result: the right view jumps to the line that was just command+clicked
Actual result: the file is opened, again, in the left view and then jumps to the line

I'd really like it if this process would first search to see if any view has the file open already.

Thanks!

_Copied from original issue: Microsoft/vscode-go#1080_

data.title: Fix #8132. Open folder in integrated terminal.
data.body:
This is the first touch on Open Folder in Integrated Terminal. Some decisions still need to be revisited

* Configuration Name. Now I call it  `terminal.terminalKind` to align with  https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/debug/common/debugProtocol.d.ts#L198 . We have put settings for integrated terminal in `parts/terminal` folder and external ones in `parts/execution`. I'm not sure putting this one into `parts/explorer` and name it as `explorer.terminalKind` would be a good idea as then we have settings for terminal in three different places.
* I didn't touch `runInTerminal` yet as it's up to the caller whether to use external or integrated terminal. For `openInTerminal`, we make the decision where we bind the action to the explorer. For `runInTerminal`, we make such decision when invoking terminals, e.g., 
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/debug/electron-browser/terminalSupport.ts#L21

data.title: fonts with plus sign in their names won't render.
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: macos 10.12.5

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install this patched font from here https://github.com/gabrielelana/awesome-terminal-fonts/blob/patching-strategy/patched/SourceCodePro%2BPowerline%2BAwesome%2BRegular.ttf
2. this font's name is `SourceCodePro+Powerline+AwesomeRegular` go to your settings.json and try to activate this font by setting the `editor.fontFamily: "SourceCodePro+Powerline+AwesomeRegular"`
3. You'll see that step 2 will not work.
4. now try setting the font like this
```
"editor.fontFamily": "\"SourceCodePro+Powerline+AwesomeRegular\"",
```

What's happening is that VSCODE won't put quotation marks around font name if there are no spaces in it. but this font name has plus signs in the name, chromium accepts that as space and won't render the font.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: VS Code Intellisense suddenly stops functioning correctly (JavaScript)
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: Windows 7 professional, 32-bit

Unsure of how to reproduce.
The issue suddenly came to be when intellisense started to think of value types as "any" and even confusing them with other value types rarely, it started right before I updated VS Code to 1.13.1.
This is mainly happening with only one node.js module that I'm using, and I'm unsure if it could be the module itself, since I have not updated the module and the issue came out of nowhere.

Here's an example:
![any](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13611030/28027877-5dced0ac-65a3-11e7-8720-1b5f1311282d.png)
Before, it used to say that the type was "Message", now, it just says "any".

Here's another example:
![any2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13611030/28028033-e754bbca-65a3-11e7-8dea-eb9e38728aba.png)
"get" does not return that type, yet intellisense fails to tell me that, again, it used to never do this before.

With a little testing on other modules, they *seem* to work fine, and the intellisense on this certain module that I'm having trouble with gets it right on some places, but not all of them.

Again, this could be a problem with VS Code, or the module itself, but the problem is so random I'm unsure of it. I've searched for an answer and I didn't get what I was looking for.

Apologies if this is not supposed to be said here, and I'll be happy to provide info you need.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Feature request: 'New project' API
data.body:
I would like to suggest an API for extensions to hook into for starting new projects of a certain type.

My motivation is creating a user-friendly way of creating a new project, similar to an experience found in Big Brother Visual Studio, but better. [CMake Tools](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=vector-of-bool.cmake-tools) provides a command `CMake: Quick Start` which creates a stub project with a single CMakeLists.txt file and a "Hello, World" level main.cpp. This is great way to skip some of the boilerplate associated by just getting a text editor with a compiler hooked up to it locally. (Something like godbolt, but locally, just to test something or get going on a new project.)

[Windows Template Studio](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=WASTeamAccount.WindowsTemplateStudio) is awesome and it were nice if a similar API could come integrated into VS Code where extensions could register their own quick start templates, or even more convoluted ones, as found in WTS.

If such a feature existed, I would gladly take the time and contribute to CMake Tools to create composable CMake script stubs. Something like:

I need a library that will:
- depend on clFFT and clBLAS
- have unit tests
- have docs created by doxygen

Plus I will need an executable:
- that links to the library
- which depends on Boost program options
- have docs created by doxygen

So something similar to WTS, but for CMake and baked into VS Code for seamless integration. Because this feature I believe is of general interest, it could be worth the effort to create an API for.

Ideas?

data.title: Wrong syntax highlighting for JavaScript with inline php code returning JavaScript objects
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Home 64-bit

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a new file with the .php extension
2. Try to assign the value returned by an inline php function to a JavaScript object.

For example:

```
<script>

    var jsObject = <?php echo json_encode($somePHPArray); ?>;
    var anotherJsObject = <?php echo json_encode($anotherPHPArray) ?>;

    var someVariable = "value";

    function storePreviousFormData(formData) {
        // some comments
    }
    
</script>
<script>
    functionInAnotherScriptBlock() {
        var hereHighlighting = "is still broken";
    }

    var colors = {
        do: "not work as they should";
    }
</script>
```

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

This is related to the issue #4646. Highlighting of the values enclosed in quotation marks works. There is a problem only with objects, since they cannot be enclosed in quotation marks.

data.title: Expand Debug API for extensions
data.body: e.g. sessionStarted, sessionTerminated, sendCustomRequest, handleCustomEvent

data.title: Experiment: remote file system
Feature Request: Clear Search Field/Halt Searching
data.body:
Hi everyone! 

Not sure if this is a feature already that I just can't seem to find, but I'd like to make a feature request if it isn't. When searching for a keyword across all files in my project, I would like to be able to clear the search field to stop a search. Currently, if I search for a keyword that might have a lot of results, I don't see any UI element to stop the search and I workaround this by just typing in some gibberish string in place of what I was originally searching for. I find that if I don't clear a search out, it slows down VS Code quite a bit, so it would be nice to be able to stop that. 

My proposed solution would be adding an 'X' button on the right side of the search field to allow for easy search term clearing. 

Thanks for hearing me out and I appreciate this product!

data.title: [scss] extend multiple classes highlighted as error
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:13:05.928Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|theme-monokai-dark-soda|AdamCaviness|0.0.5|
|Theme-FlatlandMonokai|gerane|0.0.4|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|3.1.6|
|debugger-for-ios-web|msjsdiag|0.1.2|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create `.scss` file
2. Extend two classes inside one selector, like `@extend .text-center, .uppercase;`
3. As a Problem is highlighted: 
```
severity: 'Error'
message: 'semi-colon expected'
source: 'scss'
```

It should not be an error since it's feasible in SASS to extend two classes using the comma as separation.

data.title: Display required / type quick info in the type helper
data.body:
As a feature request/suggestion:

It would be very useful if type helper would display at least what fields in the interface are required, or which can be omitted (undefined). This is really useful for new/unfamiliar libraries with complex interfaces: user can quickly define and fill required properties.

Required fields could be marked with (*) or another color.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/736697/28019388-394ff822-659a-11e7-8dc6-4b792696d857.png)

Maybe also this free space could be used to output type value preview in an unobtrusive manner.

data.title: Unable to Debug Jest tests with Typescript
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:13:05.928Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|EditorConfig|EditorConfig|0.9.3|
|npm-intellisense|christian-kohler|1.3.0|
|tslint|eg2|0.16.0|
|path-autocomplete|ionutvmi|1.5.1|
|graphql-for-vscode|kumar-harsh|1.4.2|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|3.1.6|
|vim|vscodevim|0.9.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Clone the reproduction case here: https://github.com/blargity/vscode-ts-jest-debugger
2. Run `yarn`
3. Try to run the `Tests` configuration in VSCode

---

Note: this is not the only configuration we've tried. Even setting inline source maps doesn't seem to do anything:

```
$ node --version
v8.1.2
$ npm --version
5.0.3
$ yarn --version
0.27.5
$ tsc --version
Version 2.4.1
```

I'd really appreciate any help I can get debugging this and figuring out how we can run our tests using the debugger. Once you get used to using the VSCode debugger you want to use it for everything!
